Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2010 05:01AM hmh23 wrote: CT124; At my 2nd rad treatment, I asked about blocking the thyroid and it's exposure and I was told and shown on the machine they use, that the machine itself protects all areas not meant to get any radiation whatsoever.  You might want to ask as older machines require an actual block of some sort. Heather
Posts.Title: October 2010 rads mamaof3bugs JFV

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2010 06:51AM hmh23 wrote: Joan;  What # are you on?  I just completed 15 of 33 and my skin especially around and under my armpit is tight and very red.  My rad onc came in to see it and he said it is normal at this point in my treatment. I too am tired and he said that also is expected.  I keep saying to myself, 'this too will pass', just as the nausea, the body aches, etc.  Have a great day.  Heather
Posts.Title: October 2010 rads mamaof3bugs JFV

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2010 06:10PM hmh23 wrote: I was really lucky to be given a 'dignity robe' when I started radiation. I know the name is a bit corny but it allows the technicians to lift/open up one side while leaving the other breast covered.  It has velcro down each side and down the front.  I completed #16 of 33 today and my armpit is extremely red.  They gave me a cream used on burn victims called 'silverdeam(?)' or something like that.  I'm too lazy to get up right now to look at the tube...sorry. Like many of you, I feel somewhat swollen and my skin feels very tight.  This is getting old but the light is brighter at the end of the tunnel. Fondly, Heather
Posts.Title: October 2010 rads mamaof3bugs JFV

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2011 06:48PM hmh23 wrote: Diamondgirl;  My bone-like pain actually has let up a bit but I still have burning pain.  A good friend of mine is now 10 years post radiation and she tells me that she still has pain.  I saw my onc at a birthday party and he reassured me not to worry about it.  As far as the 'lump' under your arm, I had my radiation onc look at it and he also reassured me that it was not anything to worry about...most likely scar tissue and effects of rads.  I am hoping to go to physical therapy as my chest is quite tight and my range of motion seems to be more limited now that I have healed completely from rads. I also have more pain when I work out so I've been avoidiing yoga right now and lifting any heavy weights.  They both seem to aggravate my symptoms. Hope that helps.
Posts.Title: October 2010 rads mamaof3bugs JFV

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2010 03:35PM hmh23 wrote: Count me in on this group too!  I had my first consultation today with my RO.  I will have my CT Scan on Tuesday and then simulation sometime after that.  NOt very happy that my rads will last 6 weeks,  5 plus one week of boost.  I was hoping that it would be only 4 or 5 weeks and for some reason being told it would be 6 has hit me hard.  I've managed to be pretty strong over the past 9 months since diagnosis and I just wasn't expecting 6 MORE weeks.  So here I am looking forward to gaining strength and encouragement from this group. Heather
Posts.Title: October 2010 rads mamaof3bugs JFV

Just wondering if anyone else is having discomfort on the arm where lymph nodes were radiated.  It is actually on the outside of my arm and it is not muscular or even bone pain just a constant soreness.  Heather

Good luck, Heather

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2010 06:32PM hmh23 wrote: MaryNY:  photos are spectacular.  You look absolutely beautiful!  What color was your hair before chemo?  I am on Taxol #2 and I'm seeing some hair regrowth...most of it seems to be very white with some dark brown.  I had been coloring my hair and from what my hairdresser told me, I was about 30% gray....this new hair seems to be about 75% gray.  I promised my husband, I would not dye it any longer.  He loves salt and pepper hair.  Not sure I can follow through on my promise but your photos may well be convincing me that I should stick with it!!! Heather
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2010 05:44PM hmh23 wrote: Dear Ivorymom;  I'm going to use a line from one of the other girls on the forum because it says it all about my hair growth pattern....male pattern baldness!!!  It's actually kind of funny.  I have dark hair 1/4" long all around my head and then the top has sporatic growth that is both white and dark.  I just completely my 7 of 12 Taxol treatments and my hair is growing pretty well.  I actually had to trim some really stray longer hairs already but I can't forsee going outside any time soon with nothing on my head.  I'd scare someone for sure.  Have a great day!  Heather PS.  My onc did a CA-15-3 blood test today and my  number is 14.6.  Does anyone out there know much about this test?

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2010 05:47PM hmh23 wrote: Carol; I had 3 shots of Neulasta and I never experienced any pain whatsoever.  I was scared to death of the shot but it was absolutely nothing except an inconvenience to dry down to the hospital 2 days after I finished my chemo.  Anyhow, it was worth it. Like MBJ, I too had terrible constipation... recommend taking a stool softener before you have your first chemo and continue to throughout the first 5 days following.  Also, take your anti-nausea meds as soon as you get home.  Good luck....Heather

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2010 10:13AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:03AM by hmh23 Calleigh;  We all know what you are feeling right now.  If I can give you a mantra to help you through this period, it would be, 'I'm losing my hair, but saving my life'. On another note, my 'woodstock' hair is now about 1" in length especially on top.  Along  the sides of my head (male patterned baldness) it is very fine with a great deal of white, black, brown mixed in and also about an 1" long.  I see some new growth, darker hair growing in on top as well.  I'm just not sure if I should just take the trimmers and cut off the 'feathers' because it is really itchy under my wig when I wear it (only to meetings or out for the evening) or just leave it.  Any and all advice welcome.  Thx so much, Heather

Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2010 09:52AM hmh23 wrote: Erin; Although all of us on these pages have gone through or are currently experiencing hair loss, few if any of us are as young as you are.  I remember thinking when people would say to me, 'it's only hair'...I often thought to ask them how they would feel walking around bald.  We all try to be so strong during this time, you owe it to yourself to mourn your hair loss but please remember with the process of losing your hair, you have begun the process of saving your life. I went commando, BALD last night for the first time. Even though my hair is still pretty sketchy as I am only 8 weeks PFC, I just decided that I would do it.  It was so liberating!!!!  I attended an Leukemia event of 400...got some stares but my friends and husband gave me strength to take the leap. WANDA is officially now on the shelf!!! Have a wonderful day...off to #20 of 33 radiations. Fondly, Heather

Posts.Title: Abraxane Anyone! hmh23 hmh23

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2010 04:51AM hmh23 wrote: jsw19;  My SEs have been minimal since starting Abraxane.  It's great that you aren't bombarded with Benadryl and then entire treatment is about 1/3 of the time of the Taxol treatment.  My AC wasn't that bad either.  I would recommend a stool softener right off the bat and ask your doctor for Ambien so you can sleep after it.  I had a difficult time sleeping the for two days as a result of the steroid. You can send a PM to me with any questions.  Good luck!  Heather
Posts.Title: Abraxane Anyone! hmh23 hmh23

Posts.Content: hmh23 wrote: My onc put me on Abraxane after I experienced Neuropathy on Taxol.  I had already completed 7 of my 12 Taxol when he made the move.  I now have finished 2 of the 5 Abraxane and I was wondering what type of SEs anyone may have experienced. Believe it or not, I'm most concerned about losing the hair that's already started to grow back.  Losing it the first time wasn't that upsetting for me but I'm worried sick about losing it again. Heather Realize the majority of your body is healthy! Dx 1/28/2010, ILC, 2cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 2, 5/9 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Abraxane Anyone! hmh23 hmh23

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2010 10:12AM hmh23 wrote: ButterflyBonnie;  You should definitely contact the pharmaceutical company that makes Emend and if no help there, contact the American Cancer Society.  They have programs for financial assistance. My Emend is given just before my AC treatment starts through my port and then I was prescribed 1 pill each for the 2 days following the treatment.  Also ask about the generics at your pharmacy.  If you get nowhere on the Emend, then ask your onc if a combination of drugs, ie. compazine and zofran would help as well.  In the meantime, we are all here for you.  Good luck!  Heather
Posts.Title: ADRIAMYCIN & CYTOXAN ???? BUTTERFLYBONNIE BUTTERFLYBONNIE

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2010 04:53PM hmh23 wrote: Dear Sannie; Just wanted you to know that I too have just started chemo (AC) on March 29th and my side efffects have been very manageable as well.  I did not have any terrible SEs only some minor nausea which was controlled by Zofran.  Anyhow, my SEs did not get any worse.  My hair is slowly but surely getting much thinner but that's ok. I've said it before, I'm losing my hair but saving my life. 'Wanda'  my wig is ready and waiting for me.  If you want a great book (really easy read) then I would recommend, "There's No Place Like HOPE" by Vickie Girard.  It has been my 'go to' book for inspiration and positivity! Fondly, Heather
Posts.Title: New here sannie hmh23

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2010 05:00PM - edited Apr 11, 2010 05:01PM by hmh23 Bonnie;  Just wanted to let you know you are in my thoughts and prayers.  I also wanted to let you know about a wonderful book, "There's No Place Like HOPE" written by Vickie Girard.  She was diagnosed with Stage IV in 1992 and she chose to fight and dedicated the next 17 years of her life to helping others fight the fight.  It is a wonderfully inspirational book (extremely quick read) that I go to often.  It is now colored with 3 different highlighting markers and it gives me strength and often makes me laugh.  It is important to understand the road ahead, you must talk to those coming back.  We are all coming back and we are here for you. Fondly, Heather
Posts.Title: ADRIAMYCIN & CYTOXAN ???? BUTTERFLYBONNIE BUTTERFLYBONNIE

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2010 01:11AM hmh23 wrote: Butterflybonnie;  Miralax, miralax, miralax is the only thing that helped me with my constipation.  I would also recommend a warm bath (my onc nurse gave me that as a suggestion and it helped tremendously as well).  I had terrible issues for 3 days after my 1st AC and tomorrow I head in for my second treatment. I started my miralax treatment already!! Hope it resolves itself.  Heather
Posts.Title: ADRIAMYCIN & CYTOXAN ???? BUTTERFLYBONNIE BUTTERFLYBONNIE

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2010 07:24AM hmh23 wrote: Allison;  I just wanted to pass along a name of a book that I read just after my diagnosis (1/28/2010)and it has become my 'go to' book for HOPE, dealing with the disease, telling my family, treatment and everyday life.  It is called "There's No Place Like HOPE" by Vickie Girard.  It is an extremely quick read that is a 'guide to beating cancer in mind-sized bites'.  I have learned that you have to take each step of the diagnosis, each day of your treatment plan and each day of your life in mind sized bites.  We are all here for you and as Vickie puts it in her book, "To know the road ahead, ask those coming back".  You are a survivor from the day you are diagnosed and we are all on our road back. Even though each one of our stories are different, it is all the same disease.  Just now that there is no question that can't be asked if not on a forum, you can ask anyone of these wonderful ladies privately.   Dream of wellness.  Heather
